utterance: CM: Good morning. My name is Carlos. I'm assistant professor in chemical and biomolecular, biomolecular engineering here at UCLA. My group works on understanding the role of mass transport in the selectivity during the transformation of carbon dioxide. So we think that if we can decouple mass transport from kinetic effects, we will have a better understanding of how to scale up and how to design reactors with a target selectivity for a product. Thank you. Looking forward to talking to you.

utterance: RG: I'd add to that that a lot of the heterogeneous catalysts, we don't necessarily know what the active site is and there may be a whole bunch of different active sites that have different reactivity, different product selectivity. And from the computational side, you have to model every single one of those separately to actually have any clue.

annotations.expand on existing idea: Rebecca Gieseking expands on Yuan-Yue Liu's point about the complexity of modeling heterogeneous electrocatalysis by adding the challenge of identifying the active sites in these catalysts.

utterance: RG: I also wanted to loop back to just a bigger picture question. We were talking about fuels earlier. To me, that kind of strikes me as almost counterproductive to the goal of negative emissions because if we're taking the carbon, we're sucking it out of the atmosphere and turning it into a fuel so that we can put it back into the atmosphere. Is that really negative emissions?

annotations.ask clarifying question: RG questions whether producing fuels from captured carbon truly qualifies as negative emissions, given that the carbon is ultimately released back into the atmosphere.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: RG refers back to the earlier discussion about fuels to support her point about the potential counterproductivity of turning captured carbon into fuel.
annotations.offer constructive criticism: RG critiques the idea of using captured carbon for fuel production by highlighting its potential to undermine the goal of negative emissions.
